Even if a node can process hundreds or thousands of tx/sec in a closed simulation, that does not imply that it can support a public blockchain that can process that much. My Parity node can run >500 tx/sec on my laptop, but Ethereum main chain is only processing 11.5 tx/sec.

Ethereum's *gas schedule* is definitely evolving toward more resistance over time. There are other features that have nice negative feedback effects (eg. the fact that block time targeting now includes uncles means that a DoS that doubles uncle rates would drop capacity 10-15%)

Well, then we're already in crypto 4.0 :) There have been at least three major crashes/weedouts in late 2011, mid 2013, and 2014-2015 respectively in BTC alone. Ethereum has also had at least 3 crashes (pre-launch due to BTC crash, late 2015 drop, and mid 2016 after the DAO).
